thread.title: How 5 IPOs have fared in a tough market
thread.title_full: How 5 IPOs have fared in a tough market - MarketWatch

author: Caitlin Huston   and   Tomi Kilgore
title: How 5 IPOs have fared in a tough market
text:
Getty Images Fitbit shares have fallen 15% in the last month. Slide 1 of 7 Twitter Inc.’s TWTR, -0.50% stock dipped below its IPO price for the first time Thursday, serving as a reminder that going public doesn’t ensure profitability for investors.
The Nasdaq Composite COMP, -3.52% is on track for its steepest four-day loss in about four years, and technology shares have been hit particularly hard.
The broad selloff could deter companies that had been primed to go public after Labor Day, particularly if markets remain unstable. Investors tend to turn away first from untested companies in times of trouble.
The selloff in the broader market may carry over to private companies valued at $1 billion or more that may consider going public, said Bill Gurley, general partner at venture-capital firm Benchmark, on Twitter .
“One might reasonably assume this would have an adverse impact on late stage private market liquidity and valuation. I certainly do,” Gurley tweeted.
This could also signal a change in how investors determine what companies to invest in and refocus business priorities, he said.
“Investors are likely to refocus on business model viability and path to profitability. This will seem like an abrupt sea-change to many,” he tweeted.
Here is how the shares of companies that recently went public have fared:
FactSet Slide 2 of 7 1. Fitbit Inc.
Fitbit Inc. FIT, -6.67% soared on its first day of trading back on June 18. Shares of the maker of wearable fitness trackers opened at $31, above the $20 initial public offering price, and ended the day at $29.68. Prices continued climbing, hitting a closing high of $51.64 on Aug. 5. But shares tanked after the company warned it expected lower margins, even as it beat earnings expectations. They fell sharply again on Friday, along with the broader market.
Fitbit shares have fallen 15% in the last month, compared with the S&P 500’s decline of 5%.
FactSet Slide 3 of 7 2. Etsy Inc.
Etsy Inc. ETSY, -5.54% had a strong debut on April 16, with shares opening at $30.98 versus its IPO issue price of $16. They closed at $30 that day. But it has been a different story for the crafts site since then.
In the past three months, shares of Etsy have fallen 22%, as investors have worried about the company’s high expenses, continued unprofitability and the risk that its sellers leave the platform. The one-month drop has been a steeper 29%.
Shares of Etsy were down 5% Friday.
FactSet Slide 4 of 7 3. Amplify Snack Brands Inc.
Shares of Amplify Snack Brands BETR, +5.94% have yet to trade at their IPO price of $18.
Shares of the maker of SkinnyPop popcorn — which isn’t a lower-calorie popcorn —debuted at $17 on Aug. 5 and closed at $16.14 that day. They were up sharply Friday, bucking the broader selloff, but remain more than $4 below the issue price.
FactSet Slide 5 of 7 4. Planet Fitness Inc.
This is another stock that didn’t deliver a first-day IPO pop, although it didn’t flop either.
While shares in the operator of a chain of gyms PLNT, -4.41% debuted on Aug. 6 at $14.50, below their $16 IPO price, they clawed back that day to close at the issue price.
Shares set a closing high of $18.68 on Aug. 10. But they have tumbled this week and now trade slightly above the IPO price.
The company said in its prospectus that it has $506.4 million in debt, which could hamper its growth.
FactSet Slide 6 of 7 5. Fogo de Chao Inc.
The Brazilian steakhouse chain went public on June 19 and the stock opened at $26, above its IPO price of $20. It closed at $25.75 that day.
The stock had a peak close of $26.19 on June 22, but has largely been on the decline since then with a month-to-date drop of 5%.
The stock had a recent uptick on August 19 after J.P. Morgan upgraded Fogo de Chao from overweight to neutral.
Fogo De Chao FOGO, +0.05% shares were up less than 1% Friday.
FactSet Slide 7 of 7 5. Fogo de Chao Inc.
The Brazilian steakhouse chain went public on June 19 and the stock opened at $26, above its IPO price of $20. It closed at $25.75 that day.
The stock had a peak close of $26.19 on June 22, but has largely been on the decline since then with a month-to-date drop of 5%.
The stock had a recent uptick on August 19 after J.P. Morgan upgraded Fogo de Chao from overweight to neutral.
Fogo De Chao US:FOGO shares were up less than 1% Friday.
